responses.content: Digital technology is becoming critical for core resilience and business continuity. As a tech company with a comprehensive, differentiated portfolio from business applications to infrastructure, we benefit from the structural changes in customer behavior and expectations. We are focused on the next 10 years of compute and digital technology across industries.

Our Azure differentiation comes from our hybrid leadership, new data products that are highly differentiated and competitive in the marketplace, and integration with every other layer of our stack, including Power Platform, GitHub, Teams, Power Apps, and Azure DB. Our industry solutions in healthcare and retail lead to time to value, price differentiation, cost advantage to customers, and agility in their digital capability.

Teams brings together chat, meetings, collaboration, and business processes into one scaffolding. It integrates with line of business applications across departments like HR, finance, and operations, driving usage among both knowledge workers and frontline workers by enabling digital tools in workflows.

We are very focused on modern business process applications. Customers are looking to integrate workflows into communication tools to ensure continuity between frontline, knowledge workers, and business processes. This includes leveraging Dynamics 365 alongside Azure PaaS and SaaS capabilities to transform industries like manufacturing and supply chain.

Our vision includes the Game Pass strategy to reach over 2 billion gamers through consoles, PC, mobile, and streaming services. The xCloud service allows us to expand beyond traditional endpoints, and while it's in the early innings, we are excited about the expansion opportunities it provides.

We see significant opportunities in industry verticals such as financials and manufacturing. By integrating industry-specific workflows and leveraging our comprehensive cloud stack, we enhance time to value, cost advantages, and agility for our customers.

Security remains a top priority. We are committed to helping customers implement a zero trust architecture, integrating identity, endpoint, application infrastructure, and cloud-native security solutions to enhance cyber defense and operational security posture.
In Q3, we saw strong OEM numbers with the pro-end-of-support and another strong end-of-support for the server on-premises. These are the two key factors contributing to our performance in Q3.

Azure consumption growth was driven by fundamental usage growth and reacceleration of the growth curve, particularly in industries that were more hard-hit in Q4 and Q1. The acceleration in Azure is not due to larger transaction sizes but due to consistent consumption growth and robust bookings.

Office 365 commercial penetration is now at 70%, up from 50% in 2017. We have continued to see installed base growth through adding frontline worker scenarios, increasing in SMB, and good trial conversions. We expect Office 365 growth to accelerate as seat growth, conversions, and E5 selling continue.

Our PBP guide shows consistent performance across most components with strong execution in LinkedIn, Office commercial, consumer subscriptions, and Dynamics. Office 365 saw better seat growth, trial conversions, and E5 selling, which supports future revenue growth and acceleration in Office 365.

We are seeing headcount growth of over 10% in the past year as we invest in significant opportunities and customer success. Despite remote work, we are investing in flexibility and employee support. Our expense profile remains focused on investing in customer success and adapting to new ways of working, without expecting a full return to pre-COVID expense levels.

Azure plus the annuity business represent a durable hybrid edge, cloud value. We have strong renewal rates, premium strength, and hybrid value propositions. Bookings numbers are very good with less than 12 months RPO. Azure longer contracts continue to show healthy growth.

Our cash flow should move in line with operating income, reflecting strong sales, improving margins, particularly in the cloud, and our business execution. We have focused on optimizing for customer success and strong execution.

questions: Should we feel that the COVID impact is basically behind you; and is the tougher comps or are we now seeing the demand is such that allows you to build on those larger numbers?

As you’re putting up a great accelerating quarter, could you just talk to what you’re seeing in terms of the breadth and maybe the size of the transactions, and anything else that you think is important to highlight why we’re seeing this reacceleration in the business?

Amy, I wanted to ask you about the PBP guide for your third quarter, the March quarter. It was comfortably above where everybody, I think, is modeling. And in particular, I wanted to ask you about Office 365. Of all the businesses, the larger ones in Microsoft, most of the upside in this recent quarter, except perhaps for Office 365, where despite the migration to E5 and despite the free-to-paid seat conversion, we really didn’t see an acceleration in Office 365. I’m wondering if you could perhaps unpack that and describe why and part two to the question is your guide for that segment is so good in the March quarter that one would infer that the Office 365 growth is likely to accelerate in March. I’m wondering if you could confirm whether that’s a reasonable assumption. Thanks so much.

I wanted to dig into one of the topics that you mentioned in your introduction, and that’s kind of Teams working as a framework across all of your solutions and sort of connecting more and more people into the Microsoft framework. I was doing some calls this quarter and asking about a competitor’s acquisition of a Team’s competitor. And a lot of people in the channel talked to me about how Teams was pulling through Dynamic CRM, right, and they understood that acquisition as a defense against that. And I was surprised to hear that, that there would be a linkage between the two. Can you help us, one, kind of understand how Teams pulls in additional products behind it, and two, the connection between Teams and how they get a broader base of frontline workers into the story for Microsoft, because I think most people think about Microsoft as, like, an information worker story? But frontline workers is another huge area for you guys to go after.

Amy, do you see a sustainably different post-COVID expense profile for Microsoft as it relates to real estate footprint and T&E levels? And maybe, Satya, you could perhaps comment on this as well. Are you expecting a fuller return to the office and fuller resumption of business travel over time, such that that expense profile wouldn’t look very different?

Question for Satya in how you’re thinking about the $200 billion enterprise applications market. Your market share in that area is fairly low in aggregate. You’ve got Dynamics that’s performing really well and sounds like is accelerating. Just wondering how you’re looking at that market more broadly as an opportunity for the company.

I wanted to talk a little bit about gaming. Obviously, you had a very strong quarter, but we also saw a few months ago the launch of Xbox Game Pass Ultimate or the xCloud as we knew it. Can you talk a little bit about some of the early experiences there and the importance that you see emerging for that?

Amy, the cash flow in the quarter ex the audit settlement was far ahead of everyone’s expectations, and I know you talked about billings in the quarter. But as we look forward, are there any puts and takes that we should be aware of, or should we just focus on cash flow growing pretty much in line with net income? Thanks.
